item.title: Hot Wheels Let’s Race: Ultimate Speed Releases October 2025
item.content:encoded:
GameMill Entertainment has announced that Hot Wheels Let’s Race: Ultimate Speed will launch in October 2025.

The game, scheduled for release on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S/X, PC, and Nintendo Switch, will launch October 24, 2025, and is based on the popular Netflix Hot Wheels Let’s Race TV series.

You can watch the full trailer for the game below:

Hot Wheels Let’s Race: Ultimate Speed will launch for £34.99/€39.99, with a Digital Deluxe Edition costing £39.99/€49.99. The Digital Deluxe will contain the High Voltage Speed DLC Pack, including new cars, track parts for the track builder, and decals and can also be bought separately after launch for £12.99/€14.99.

Key features include:

● MEET THE RACERS: Play as your favorite Let’s Race characters, including Coop, Spark, Mac, Brights, Axle, and Cruise.

● HOT WHEELS ICONS & TRACKS: Choose from a lineup of iconic Hot Wheels vehicles, like the GT-Scorcher, Super Twin Mill, Roger Dodger, and Duck N’ Roll, each with their own unique handling, abilities, and style. Zoom through 12 wild, over-the-top tracks based on the series.

● BOSS SHOWDOWNS: Face off against massive bosses, like Professor Rearview’s giant cobra and his fire-breathing dragon, in fast-paced, action-packed battles on the track. Each encounter brings unforgettable moments at the finish line.

● RACE TO WIN: There are five thrilling gameplay modes including Racing Camp, Cup Champ, Speed Trials, Track Builder, and Free Races. Featuring fast, fluid controls built for high-speed competition, race solo or with friends in local four-player split-screen.

● ULTIMATE CUSTOMIZATION: Earn flame badges to unlock new cars, decals, and track parts in the Ultimate Garage. Customize your own Hot Wheels car and show it off on the track.

Will you be playing Hot Wheels Let’s Race: Ultimate Speed? Let me know on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Beta Gets New Map and Modes This Week
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6 players will be able to access two new game modes and a new map during the upcoming open beta weekend.

Battlefield 6’s open beta was the biggest beta test yet for the franchise, bringing in over 500,000 concurrent players on Steam alone. However, it did come with some minor issues that developers are figuring out, including “unexpectedly fast” time to death. Developers will try to iron out any problems they can before the next BF6 Open Beta weekend arrives, featuring a new map and modes.

Battlefield 6 Open Beta Weekend 2 Will Add Empire State with Rush and Squad Deathmatch Modes

Spotted by Gamesradar+, Daniel Cambran, environment artist at EA Dice, posted about Battlefield 6’s open beta weekend on their X account (formerly Twitter). The developer first thanked players for testing out the title and providing feedback. In the upcoming weekend, players get to do it all over again, but on a brand new map, Empire State and two new game modes, Rush and Squad Deathmatch.

The upcoming Battlefield 6 beta weekend will also have maps and modes from the previous weekend, including Siege of Cairo, Liberation Peak and Iberian Offensive. Modes of the prior weekend included Conquest, Closed Weapon Conquest, Breakthrough, Domination and King of the Hill. BF6 Open Beta Weekend 2 will also include Closed Weapon Conquest and Breakthrough.

In other news, the viral VTuber ‘RileyCS’ has been banned on Twitch following allegations of cheating. Additionally, BF6’s anti-cheat engine is asking players to uninstall Valorant. item.title: FBC: Firebreak Launch Deemed Unsatisfying And Underperformed, Major Update Coming
item.content:encoded:
You can’t deny FBC: Firebreak is ambitious, even if it is a game no one was necessarily clamoring for. The latter part of this is now evident, as Remedy has given deeper insight into FBC: Firebreak’s underwhelming launch and plans for the IP.

FBC: Firebreak was Remedy’s first new release since the Game of the Year-contending Alan Wake 2. Firebreak is set in Control’s (another Remedy IP) world and is a team-based FPS. This is quite a bold shift from the company’s other games. We’ve seen from gameplay and matches that the game has potential, but its launch has failed to land.

FBC: Firebreak Receiving Major Update in September

It’s quite damning to hear that the FBC: Firebreak “launch underperformed.” This is the official word from Remedy’s Jan-Jun 2025 financial report.

“On Steam, which was planned as the primary consumer sales channel on PC, the launch underperformed. The game’s initial onboarding experience and mission structure resulted in high early player drop-offs and an influx of negative reviews.”

The company was happy that “The launch succeeded technically, reaching over 1 million players in its first 10 days,” but goes on to say: “Commercially, we were unsatisfied with the launch-phase consumer sales of FBC: Firebreak.”

The majority of the shooter’s revenue has come from Xbox Game Pass and PlayStation Plus-subscribing users. Firebreak was free on both services at launch.

Nevertheless, despite the adversity, Remedy believes FBC: Firebreak is a “solid game” the team can build on: “Looking ahead, a larger ‘Major Update’ late September will be the next key step for FBC: Firebreak. This will be supported by targeted marketing activities, which we expect to drive interest in the title. We are committed to continuing to work on FBC: Firebreak, engaging with the community, and expanding the game.”

Do you think Firebreak can bounce back? With so many live-service games out there, it’s tough to stand out. Let me know if you think it can by heading to the Insider Gaming forum.

There’s more Remedy news to check out, including Rockstar Games working with Remedy Entertainment on the Max Payne 1 & 2 Remake and a new report on Control 2’s development.

item.title: Control 2 Development Gets Update From Remedy As Series Crosses 5 Million Copies Sold
item.content:encoded:
Remedy has been distracted by other games in recent years. But Control 2 is one of the company’s biggest upcoming projects, and not only have we learned new details about the game’s progress, but the company has announced a huge milestone for the franchise.

Control felt interesting until the game’s final moments: The puzzles, the paranormal activity in the environment, and your powers. It felt like something was always happening. It could see-saw from horror to hot action in a heartbeat. The demand for a second game has been strong for a while, and it appears the sequel is getting closer.

Control 2 Development is “On Track,” Says Remedy Entertainment

The 2025 Remedy Half-year financial report told us several things: Rockstar and Remedy are working together on the Max Payne 1 & 2 Remake, the Control franchise has surpassed 5 million lifetime copies sold and counting, and Control 2 is coming along nicely.

Here’s the official word on Control 2’s development: “Control 2 development is on track towards meeting its next milestones. The focus is now on the gameplay, environments, and missions. Work continues on developing the game into a strong commercial offering.”

The next milestones could be an official reveal trailer or even a gameplay reveal right out of the gate. I think it’s safe to assume from this that we’re still quite some way off from Control 2 hitting shelves and digital storefronts, though.

One thing’s for sure: Remedy has a lot on its plate with FBC Firebreak, the Max Payne Remake, and Control 2.

What did you love most about the first Control? For me, it was all of it, to be honest. I want to hear what you think, and you can get a conversation underway courtesy of the Insider Gaming forum.
